Yeah. Well, I think, Michael that is a traditional question, so therefore, you will get a traditional answer, that we complete the annual ceremony. We have replaced the U.S. reserving, which I think it's not really benefit in the past by our Zurich way of reserving. And so – and keep our prudent approach and we are not making any specific forecasts about the positive run-off, but we feel that we also don't see any changes in the reserve quality to previous years. And I think there was also a hidden indication by John actually that we – that probably reserves are assuming a higher inflation ratio for 2009 than we would now all estimate what will really happen in 2009.
Thank you very much.

If I could just add one point on this because it's an interesting aspect in the recessionary piece, because two of the more recent initiatives within the Zurich Way of claims have to do with a global approach to fraud and a global approach to procurement, which I think for us really will help us stay ahead of the issue of what types of claims might be coming and emerging out of the recessionary environment.
Okay. Now to give everybody a fair chance we're down to one part questions. So if you give us three parts, we'll answer the first one. Brian (1.47.03), would you like to start.
Okay, I'll try to squeeze everything into one question.
[laughter] That's what Michael did.

It goes back to one of Jim's opening remarks. From a position of strength you're willing to look at opportunities now. And the question is what kind of opportunities? In the past you've answered this question by giving two or three different geographies. I could ask you maybe do you have a general preference or philosophical preference for non-life or life? And in terms of the health of the target would you buy a less cheap good company, or do you have an interest in the real bargain basement fixer-uppers?

Well, I'm going to give you the same answer I always give you, that I don't comment on acquisition rumors and the like – but I don't mean that negatively. Look, I think there are a lot of opportunities and we have to go through, and my own criteria is most acquisitions and particularly most mergers are not successful. That's my starting off point. And I said earlier, that when I look at these transactions most important thing for me is, can we maintain our culture in doing and add value in the transaction.

And by that I mean it's extremely important, if you look at the resiliency and the way we operate some people will not be able to come in to an organization and operate this way. Some companies will not be able to transform and bring value in her. So as we go through, everybody, existing businesses and potential acquisitions are competing for the same capital. And we have to make up our bets in those areas where we feel we can create the greatest amount of shareholder value, obviously evaluate the risk relative to that, and drive the greatest return.

What might appear as a great deal, as you describe a fixer-upper, may not be executable at the end of the day and expose us to lot more risk where on the other hand what may not appear to you to be from that standpoint as much value as a fixer-upper may create much more value for us over the near-term and the long-term given. So it's hard to say, we are looking for – we are a bottom feeder and we are only looking for these kinds of transactions.

And let me also say in this period, our focus is on maintaining and preserving our capital base for our existing customers and shareholders. We have got to be prudent from that standpoint and if we do look at acquisitions, we're mindful of the fact that we will have to justify those acquisitions to people that we will ask to help us finance them. So there are a lot of hurdles to overcome.

I think the other thing that I feel very good about over this last period of time is we've demonstrated a track record that we know how to integrate companies. We have a team of people that focus on the Zurich Way, bring it in to the organization and allow us to extract value in a very meaningful way. Whether it's Bristol West which you can see, and the speed which we were able to close and begin the integration of Banco Sabadell.
Okay. We are in the same house, so I'm going to take one in the middle here.

Thank you. It's William Hawkins at KBW. I had a few follow-on questions. But the core thing I wanted to ask really, on your dividend, if you could just elaborate again on your thought process behind the cut, and just factually, do you consider that you have re-based the dividend to 11? Would you consider that what you've done is a one-time cut from the original base of 15 based on the exceptional circumstances of last year?

We don't -- I don't look at the dividend as a cut. I look at the dividend in terms of our total capital management policy, and I look at it in terms of the confidence, as we've said in the sustainability of the earnings. And we will set the dividend based upon the capital needs of the organization, the economic environment that we are in. And we feel very confident with the return that you look at the yield from this dividend and also the payout ratio.

And we think that's good for this particular circumstance, of where we are. We don't designate if you read our dividend policy, we don't specifically state here is a payout ratio, here is a yield that we want to maintain. And we don't take these decisions lightly, as you can imagine, but I think you've gotten to know me over the last several years. I don't take any decisions lightly.
Okay Christian (1.52.18).

Yeah, thank you. It's a very simple question, it's the financial debt issued by Zurich, please discuss and in answering that question maybe you'd like to consider your current maturing profile, your needs, the state of the market, and whether you think that Deutsche Bank has given a free option to every house or every issuer with a callable bond, in terms of whether you think you can stay close to the debt market or whether you cannot call bonds and still meet your financing needs.
Since that's a German institution, I'm going to ask Dieter to reply.

I think we have shown over the last years that we call maturing papers at their right call date. I think we have a maturity profile in our financial statement, but we will always look also at optimization of this overall debt portfolio. And when the market is at the right point and the financing conditions are good, then certainly we will make use of it, throughout this year. That would be really wrong not to do it. I think we had the last issue in September, I think that was a very good window of opportunity, we paid a spread of 60 / 70 base points, and certainly we are looking further for these opportunities.

Actually in the fourth quarter we bought some of our outstanding debt back, where the seller was looking for liquidity and it was a bargain, so it would have been stupid not to do it, and the other way we would also issue, yeah.
Okay, we just have – Rob Haim please in the middle her, and then we'll take one more after that, which I will take...
Rob Haim JPMorgan Assets Management. Couple of questions. First one, is can you comment on your succession planning, following your announcement to step down or retire?

And secondly, can you actually – you're always quoted as a main beneficiary of the AIG demise in the US? Can you actually give us an indication what type of premiums you might be expecting to achieve there from their demise, and what are the costs that you've borne so far from the number of hirings you've done from AIG?

So, I am not sure if you want me to hand out my resume at this point in time. When I renewed my contract in 2006, we set for me the definitive date, the end of 2009. I have been working, and I think it's the job of every CEO, to put in place and provide to the Board candidates – succession candidates both internally and externally. I've been working with the Board over the last several years, to provide them with choices that they can evaluate.

I am a firm believer in the sense that you should – there is never a good time to leave. There is also a reason to stay on, and I think some people stay on longer than they should. I had in my own mind that I would not fall victim to that in terms of saying I'm indispensable. So that's why I've stuck to this timetable. The Board understands that. We've discussed it several times over the last several years, and I feel good about where we are.

No company is dependent upon any one individual. We've built a very strong organization with a sustainable strategy and sustainable operating plans that should take us through the future. And I'm sure my successor will do much better than I've done. I'm betting on it, I'm a shareholder. And I think that's the legacy I would like to leave here and I'll talk more about that as the date gets closer.

What I plan to do? I plan to run this company until the end of the year. That's what I agreed with the Board. I'm the CEO until the end of the year. I will wrap up and my focus and dedication will be on running the company. And I will look at other opportunities as they arise and when there is something to announce I'll say it.

As it relates to AIG, I think we've been very successful in recruiting talent from AIG. John can – John and Mario and the others can elaborate on that talent. We've been successful in integrating that talent into Zurich. I think that when we look at new business submissions they're up. I'm encouraged by that. We are winning business. I am concerned at times in terms of the overall industry. We will not chase pricing down in this market and I think that everyone knows both in the organization and outside of the organization, I think you destroy value by trying to buy business, particularly in this economic time and I'm concerned about some of what I see, but overall I think the market has been fairly disciplined. I don't know if John, do you want to --

Sure. And I think this is spread out actually amongst the three segments, where talent has been brought in from AIG, from fairly senior talent in the organization to subject matter experts, technical people with strong technical expertise in various areas of the business. We've gotten I'd say about a third of the people we've gotten have been outside of the United States, bringing in a lot of the international expertise that has come in – that AIG has had.
Should we, can we talk about the numbers or is that...?
People.

Oh yes. I think we're about as of January 1, we had about 60 – or just short of 60 people joining us. And they have – we think it's been a great transition including, most recently, one of their government affairs people in Washington but most of them are in the operational and technical side of the insurance businesses in Life and in General insurance as it's played out.

If I could just add one little piece to that. It's true as John said there's been a migration of talent from AIG to Zurich but I would also say that from where we started, if you will, with this leadership team in 2002 to where we've been able to bring the organization today, it's been a tremendous run and we think it's going to continue to be. So we've been able to on-board talent from other really top brand companies beyond AIG as well whether that be Hanover, whether that be USAA, whether that be Travelers, these are all top brand companies and very, very good people. And I think it just speaks to their confidence of joining an organization that already has a good proven track record and a very exiting future.

Yeah, if I can just make a quick comments on Life. We certainly widened the Life team around the world in 2008. And part of the people we recruited came from AIG. The competencies we were looking for in 2008 were technical competencies because we wanted to have underwriters because of the protection growth that we saw in the world, and also we looked carefully at people with the distribution in customer contacts in areas of the world where we wanted to grow, primarily Middle-East and Asia. And I think we have a remarkable successes in making these people interested to us and buying to our strategy and joining us.

And in terms of the cost, I mean the cost is simply to recruit these people and frankly it doesn't really change our numbers. On the other side, it give us really the opportunity now to develop customers on product lines or in regions where we did not have before the possibility to grow.
Okay. We just – we are running over time but one very quick question from Tony (2.01.54).

I was just wondering if you could remind us a bit of what's in the Other businesses segment, and why it's sensitive, what is there that is sensitive to equity market falls outside of obviously Farmers Re?

And if I can just tag one other thing on to that. The operating variances in the EV reporting include mortality persistency expenses, and then on page 249 you will see there is a plus 422 million under Other. And I was wondering what that might be please?
I think for this is question on the EV under Other, hopefully we have to follow up on those details...

While Dieter is – let me come back to the creation of this Other which came out of the turnaround, where we -- and the design was to run that business to zero over time, and a lot of that was the old Centre businesses, Zurich Capital Market businesses, which we put in there, and we had reserved, and some of that I think we've mentioned is because of the way we've done the funding and the mark-to-market write downs against assets and liabilities, and while we've earmarked assets to match to the run off timetable of some of those contracts, because of the accounting convention you are taking write downs now although they are perfectly matched against the liability and you are not writing the liability down. So you're getting some sensitivity against that.

As Jim just said, this basis mismatch we have in Centre's visibility book has both sides going through fair value, so that will swing back when the bonds are maturing. So that is -- I think if -- as we have no indication that we have to impair any of the bonds that is in the end a temporary event. On Zurich Capital Markets, we are holding still one-third of our ongoing hedge fund investments. They were historically, they are part of our active investments portfolio so they are actually not in runoff, and we have left it in the balance sheet for historical reasons, but has actually nothing to do with the original Zurich Capital Markets' business, or with the run-off portfolio. So, therefore, the hedge fund losses have to a large extent crystallized under Zurich Capital Markets.

And then we have the one-off businesses from KILICO, which we did not sell back in 2003. This life book is in run-off since October, November 2001. And some of these policies have interest guarantees or are linked to equity levels and there we increased the reserves.

Okay. Thank you very much everyone for participating. I think someone mentioned earlier, we know there is a demand on your time; sometimes there are surprise events, which surprise all of us, which take some of you away. We appreciate that and really appreciate the fact that you joined us.

One thing I want to say, I hope we've made evident to you that I feel personally very confident in this management team. I am very confident that Zurich is well positioned to navigate through these turbulent times. Like a good athlete I sometimes think we trained to be prepared for this kind of time. I know at times people thought perhaps we were too cautious, perhaps we were a bit more on the conservative side, but if I go back and look at this industry in my entire career, this is an industry where there are more variables than I've seen in any other industry.

This is an industry where there are more outside influences that you find it difficult to control and I think it's extremely important as we set out on our journey in 2002, that we put in place the operational capabilities embodied in the Zurich Way to enable us to control the things that we can control.

We demonstrate a profound appreciation for risk. I think that that's something if you look inside the crisis we find ourselves in today, which was led into by the financial community was an under appreciation of enterprise wide risk and an under pricing of risk. We have a great appreciation for risk and we look at it in our investment portfolio, in how we approach our underwriting and in our capital management strategies as we operate this organization.

And as I said earlier, we possess one of the best management teams in this industry, a growing talent pool of young and upcoming individuals. And this pool of people can control what we can control because we have not only the people but the processes and procedures and the checks and balances to ensure that we do.

That does not in any way mean that we don't continue to feel the strains of this crisis and the global recession. But it does mean that we have the tools and the mindset, and that we are aware and that we are on top of the issues and that we need to be sure that we influence our own destiny and turn this period of adversity into an era of opportunity for the Zurich.

Thank you all very, very much. I really again appreciate the time and patience that you've taken and for those of you who we didn't have a chance to answer your questions, please call the Investor Relations office and we'll get you an answer. Thank you.
